comments.text:
+Darren O'Rorke I noticed that you stated, "Is it a good thing, no as I 
find the whole idea of this disgusting."

Here's a few hypothetical situations to consider.

Scenario#1 - Suppose that you own a print shop.  A Bill was recently passed 
that in your town that requires all students to pray in school.  The school 
approaches you with a request to print the prayer book that will be used in 
classes.  Imagine if you were told you that had to print the prayer books 
for be faced with a lawsuit?

Scenario #2 - Suppose that I own a print shop.  The KKK comes to my shop 
and asks me to print a flyer explaining why blacks are not 'fully human'.  
I am married to an African-American.  Imagine that I am told that I must 
print the flyer, or I will face a lawsuit for denying equal services.

Scenario #3 - Suppose that I am gay.  Me and my partner decide that we are 
going to get a photographer.  After interviewing a photographer, he states 
that he is sorry, but due to his religious convictions he cannot photograph 
our wedding because it would promote a marriage that he believes would 
violate god's principles and participate in an act that would not only be 
against God, but also assist the couple in an act that might send them to 
hell.  My partner and I decide that we will file a lawsuit against the 
photographer.

Now, I realize that these scenarios are not exactly the same.  However, 
which of these situations uses the threat of force and coercion to make 
someone do something they believe is morally wrong?  Who is damaged by the 
use of force in these situations?
I find all three of the agents attempting to use coercion and force 
disgusting. 

I think we all like laws when they work in our favor or agree with our 
views, however we rarely are willing to give up some privileges to ensure 
that more are universally available for others.  The school can get another 
print shop, the KKK can get another print shop and the couple can find 
another photographer.

Just some alternate perspectives to consider.
comments.author: Eric Price

comments.text:
+Ess Dee *just one question.... Do you believe the right for someone to use 
any service or buy any product is more important or less important than the 
vendors right to make that service or product available to whom they 
choose?*

You offer two unpalatable choices, neither of which involve excluding a 
members of an oppressed minority. If it makes you feel any better, I have 
excluded people from my business. They also know what they need to do to 
use my business again. I have also closed early on short notice. I reserve 
the right to limit quantities...

I do not believe that you can give a definition of what is an essential 
service. Is housing an essential service? Is the house that I rent out 
essential, when there are places for rent? Assuming that someone has a 
place to live with electricity and the internet, are there any other 
essential services. You can heat and cool your home with electricity. You 
can buy everything else essential over the internet.

Is a coffee shop where community members hang out essential to a person new 
to the community trying to fit in? Is massage essential when a doctor 
doesn't prescribe it, even if energizes a person to get work done in less 
than half the time they might creep painfully through?

If someone does not act like a danger, is not obnoxious, and doesn't 
monopolize a resource, then I would say the right to buy is paramount.

I still wonder what theology, or lack of theology, you use to support your 
views.
comments.author: Norm Englund

comments.text: I could agree with you on that assessment +Darren O'Rorke
comments.author: Eric Price

comments.text:
From my point of view if it is a private business owner that does not 
provide an essential service that is required for all members of society, 
then yes they have the right of refusal. Is it a good thing, no as I find 
the whole idea of this disgusting. Now on the other hand if it is demanded 
to be an essential service weather it is a private, public or government 
run business then no they do not. What I mean by essential service is open 
for debate but I think you get the point I am trying to make.

We truly live in the Land of Confusion....one day I hope to wake up to find 
that this is not the case.

In the event of the Holocaust, Nazis believed (religiously, I might add)

their religious beliefs, right? Religious freedom, no matter who suffers!

How do you think gay people feel in Arizona? Do you even care? Let's make 
it a little less "extreme", for lack of a better word. Jesus spoke out 
against divorce and unwed mothers. He didn't say anything about 
homosexuality, though, but let's keep on track. Is it therefore okay for a 
Catholic business owner to refuse an unwed mother/divorced woman service? 
It could very well be against his religion. How would you feel if you were

top_comment.text:
Only 2.7% of populations identifies themselves as gay and lesbians, 23.2% 
of population identifies themselves as churchgoing Christians, and 27% of 
all churchgoing Christians are supporting same-sex marriage in general.
 
Support for idolatry (pornography), fornification (premarital 
co-habitation), adultery (sometimes ok for marital infidelity), divorce 
(supporting divorce for marriages with kids for reasons other than if 
abused), abortion rights is much higher for churchgoing Christians who 
support SSM than churchgoing Christians who are against SSM.  Gays and 
lesbian support for the above behavior is much stronger with gays and 
lesbians who are non-Christians being the highest.

The data comes from a recent research which surveyed 15,738 of Americans, 
ages 18-60.  The sample was nationally representative and tracked Christian 
Sexual Morality in a same-sex marriage future.  The survey was published in 
Public Discourse (The Witherspoon Institute) by Mark Regnerus. (
http://www.thepublicdiscourse.com/2014/08/13667/)

The researcher in the study relied on the Relationships in America survey, 
a data collection project he oversaw that interviewed 15,738 Americans, 
ages 18-60, in early 2014. It’s a population-based sample, meaning that its 
results are nationally representative.

Sample size:       
Churchgoing Christians who oppose SSM         2,659   (16.9%)
Churchgoing Christians who SUPPORT SSM        990    (6.3%)
Gay and Lesbian Christians                                     191    (1.2%)
Gay and Lesbian non-Christians                             233   (1.5%)
Population Avg                                                     15,738  
(100%)

First thing I learned was that only 2.7% of population identifies 
themselves as gay and lesbian – so the whole issue of pushing LGBT agenda 
on the entire population is really amazing.  45% of gays and lesbians 
identified themselves as Christians.

About 23.2% of population identified themselves as churchgoing Christians 
who have definite view on same-sex marriage – either ‘for’ or ‘against it’ 
- In order to ensure this is not just an exercise in documenting the 
attitudes of Christians “in name only,” the researcher has restricted the 
analysis to churchgoing Christians—here defined as those who report they 
attend religious services at least three times a month and who 
self-identified with some sort of Christian affiliation. And he has 
restricted the analysis to those who report a position either for or 
against same-sex marriage. (The researcher has excluded the one-in-four who 
reported they are undecided.)

The fraction of Christians who support of SSM is 27% of all churchgoing 
Christians.

The survey asked respondents to indicate their level of agreement or 
disagreement with the seven statements, five of which I listed below:
(1)    Saying that viewing pornography is OK (form of idolatry)
(2)    Saying Premarital cohabitation is good (fornification)
(3)    Saying Marital infidelity is sometimes OK (adultery)
(4)    Saying Couples with kids should stay married except if abused 
(against divorce)
(5)    Supporting abortion rights
 
Percent of population supporting the moral issues above:
Churchgoing Christians who oppose SSM        4.6% (1)   10.9% (2)    1.3% 
(3)      52.2% (4)     6.5% (5) 
Churchgoing Christians who SUPPORT SSM  33.4% (1)   37.2% (2)   7.5% 
(3)      33.5% (4)   39.1% (5)
Gay and Lesbian Christians                            57.0% (1)   49.7% 
(2)  14.2% (3)     22.9% (4)    57.5% (5)
Gay and Lesbian non-Christians                     78.1%  (1)   74.1% (2)  
26.9% (3)    18.5% (4)    71.7% (5)
Population Avg                                                31.4%  (1)   
43.0% (2)   7.5% (3)      26.9% (4)    37.8% (5)

There is more to sexual and relationship morality than just these five 
items, to be sure, but they do offer us a glimpse into how people perceive 
various practices and relationships.

On Abortion rights views:
In comparison to churchgoing Christians who oppose SSM, Gay and lesbian 
non-Christians’ support for abortion is almost 11 times higher, Churchgoing 
Christians supporting SSM is 6 times higher, and gay and lesbian Christians 
is more than 8 times.

On Pornography views:
In comparison to churchgoing Christians who oppose SSM, Gay and lesbian 
non-Christians support for pornography is 17 times higher, churchgoing 
Christians supporting SSM is 7 times higher, gay and lesbian Christians is 
more than 12 times higher.

On Support for marital infidelity (sometimes):
In comparison to churchgoing Christians who oppose SSM, gay and lesbians 
non-Christians support for adultery is 20 times higher, churchgoing 
Christians supporting SSM is almost 6 times higher, gay and lesbian 
Christians is almost 11 times higher.

On Fornification (pre-marital cohabitation):
In comparison to churchgoing Christians who oppose SSM, gay and lesbians 
non-Christians support for fornification is almost 7 times  higher, 
churchgoing Christians supporting SSM is 3 times higher, gay and lesbian 
Christians is 4 times higher.

On support for divorce (for marriages with kids for reasons other than 
abuse):
In comparison to churchgoing Christians who oppose SSM, gay and lesbians 
non-Christians support for divorce is almost 3 times  higher, churchgoing 
Christians supporting SSM is 1.5 times higher, gay and lesbian Christians 
is more than 2 times higher.

We can the pattern here – that groups that support SSM are much more open 
to what I call various sinful behavior and moral decadency which is 
especially striking with the liberal views on pornography, adultery and 
abortion.

In my view this is what Paul calls “minds which were darkened” in Rom 1:21 
– Persistence in sin has damaging effects on the human faculties: the mind 
gradually darkens to a point of intellectual blindness, and the heart 
gradually hardens and grows cold to the love and laws of God (Eph 4:17).﻿

comments.text:
+Michael.YouTube First off, evolution doesn't MAKE you believe in god. We 
are all born without knowing anything about religion or "god". A belief in 
a supernatural deity came about because early humans did not have the 
knowledge of the world around them to understand nature. Remember, they 
used to believe the sun moved while the earth didn't. We know that to be 
false because we've been into space and seen it with our own eyes.

Secondly, you are presuming that humans are the end point when you say they 
are "elevated so much than any other thing." There are many other lifeforms 
on this planet that are nearly as intelligent as humans are, with the 
ability to create and use tools, and communicate with other members of 
their own kind (some of them can even communicate with us when they learn 
to do so, ie. a gorilla that has been taught sign language).

Thirdly, humans haven't always been the highest-order animal on the planet. 
Dinosaurs once held that position. It's likely that millions of years from 
now, humans won't exist. Another creature may surpass us on the 
evolutionary scale.

Fourthly, evolution doesn't happen at a constant speed for every organism. 
For some creatures, it can move faster than for others. Humans evolved more 
quickly than gorillas because we migrated further away from our original 
geographic location and adapted to those environments, thereby 
"fast-tracking" us in a sense.

Fifthly, if you're so big on DEFINITIVE proof, then why do you believe in a 
god? It seems illogical to me that you would believe in a supernatural 
entity such as "god" when there's no proof that such a thing exists either.

comments.text:
+1989Nihil "Dark Ages actually weren't that dark."

They weren't as dark as traditionally portrayed, and they only effected 
western Europe, but that doesn't mean that it was all nice and cozy. The 
vast majority of the population were feudal serfs tied to some lord's 
estate. Conflict was virtually constant as said lords quarreled over land 
and title. Literacy and learning was only widespread among the clergy and 
knowledge in pretty every area(save for theological discourse and church 
architecture) stagnated or was lost completely. Imagine how many documents 
and histories from the classical age were lost after the fall of the 
Western Roman Empire?

The fact that Renaissance could only really start once the eastern Romans 
began fleeing the Ottoman onslaught with the recorded knowledge of the 
Eastern Empire should tell you how much was lost to the West as it 
descended into feudal ignorance. 

In terms of medicine, government and law, engineering and architecture, 
military capability and organization, philosophical discourse, and even the 
standards of living, the roman world of Trajan outpaced the best of Feudal 
Europe. That's why it's called a dark age.
comments.author: Mattheaus The Apostate

comments.text:
Hello Robert:

As for your appeal to my humanity, maybe I should have expanded a little 
more on the first sentence of the last paragraph of my previous retro.
 
This being said, you will convene that reactions of all sorts have to 
be expected each time the views of the LGBT community overflow into the 
public square or political arena. Of course, political safeguards have and 
should be insured to protect minorities against the whims of the majority. 
But does this automatically entail that we invariably have to espouse 
the views of the few because it is supposedly the right thing to do? In 
this regard, as David Letterman would like us to think, we are not talking 
here about the scourge of slavery where the whip, torture and segregation 
were the order of the day. We are talking about a rather new 
phenomenon that encroaches on the deep seated values of family life and 
religion from which this country benefited so much and even bloomed.

I fully realize that those views, all conservative they may sound, might 
not appeal to the more liberal voices. To abdicate them however, even so 
slightly, would only signify that they always were retrograde and thus all 
the more disposable. If you doubt me, ask around you, and do not forget to 
keep me posted.

Peace
comments.author: Denis Mailloux

comments.text:
I have no quarrel with open, honest political debate.  You have every right 
to speak your mind and your heart.  I suppose I had hoped to appeal to your 
sensibilities as a brother in humanity, to see if there was some way I 
could help you see that our struggle goes much deeper than politics.  It is 
intrinsic to my humanity, actually.  I really hope and believe that if good 
people really understood how difficult it is for gender "queer" people to 
live in American society, they would soften their condemnation of us and 
maybe even see that we just want to be treated with respect and accorded 
the same freedoms and responsibilities under the law, nothing more or less. 
 But, if you are not so inclined, I thank you for your attention.  Be happy 
and well.
comments.author: Robert Knight

comments.text:
+Robert Knight

Thank you for your retro. I would be pleased to discuss it but I think you 
have just pointed out the main reason why, as a Catholic, I object to the 
gay lifestyle being propelled at the forefront of the public discourse. 
Yes, It is truly a political agenda aimed at reshaping society to the core, 
with ramifications not only at the family but also at the religious and 
economic levels. LGBT is indeed a political movement. Homosexualism, if we 
could call it so, therefore opens itself to a justified criticism on the 
public place.

Far from me to condemn, shun or even ostracize homosexuals. However, I do 
not see why I should refrain from speaking against what you adequately 
called their political agenda.
comments.author: Denis Mailloux

comments.text:
No one has to "accept homosexuality as being good" but that doesn't mean 
they  they should have the right to discriminate against others based on 
that. I have the right to think whatever I want about the choices others 
make that don't affect me, but that doesn't mean I have the right to treat 
people based on what I think of their personal choices. Now I see nothing 
wrong with homosexuality and I don't believe it is a choice, but let's look 
at another example. There are people who choose to have polyamorous 
relationships. Now personally I have difficulty believing such 
relationships can actually be healthy and not harmful to the people 
involved, but that would not give me the right to fire someone if I were to 
find out they were in such a relationship. I don't have to like anyone's 
personal choices or think that they are "good", but I have to respect those 
choices. If I were an employer, it should not be my right to hire or fire 
people based on whether or not I approve of their sex lives, unless I have 
reason to believe they've perpetrated something non-consensual or anything 
involving children.

comments.text:
Consider a few items, please:
1- The law doesn't apply only to tiny shops. Any business can refuse 
service to anyone for religious reasons (homophobia is only the more 
visible aspect of it, right now.) and I think it applies to the public 
sector as well. Imagine firemen refusing to put out a fire in a gay 
household, or an EMT refusing aid to a pregnant Muslim woman.
2- Businesses are free to reject business for many reasons, and most of 
them do put up signs saying "we reserve the right to refuse service". 
However when that's enshrined into law specifically for religious reasons, 
it sets a very dangerous precedent where religious affiliation trumps 
federal law and the Constitution.
3- Even if the law were to apply only to small businesses, it could still 
be very problematic in smaller towns and neighborhoods where people simply 
cannot go to another store, for example.
4- Finally, the definition of "strongly held religious belief" is very 
nebulous. What religious belief? How do you measure the depth of it? Would 
be correct for a Muslim to refuse service to non-Muslims? Would a 
Pastafarian be justified in throwing out Christians? That sword can cut on 
both sides, bud
comments.author: elie challita

comments.text:
+xhoggerx129
Because people are fully capable of leaving their gun at home or simply not 
carrying it into a business, and the business isn't depriving you of your 
right to own a gun. Homosexuals, on the other hand, cannot simply be rid of 
their sexual orientation. That's the difference. In addition, most 
businesses that prohibit carrying firearms do so because they fear that 
such weapons will be used in robberies or cause accidents.
         Anti-Discrimination laws exist because oftentimes it is not just a 
single business that does not wish to serve a group of people, and such 
widespread denial of service can leave people without essentials like 
lodgings (Hotels would be able to refuse services), food (Grocery stores 
and restaurants), and common house items.
        I actually agree with you that the gay couple who couldn't get that 
photographer to work for them should find another one (Though they also 
have a right to expose him for being a bigot) because it's quite easy to 
find another photographer, and ultimately having a photographer isn't 
essential.
        But that's not the point of this bill. This bill allows ANY 
business to discriminate based on sexual orientation. Hospitals, Schools, 
just getting a fucking job, all would now be able to discriminate in the 
name of "religious freedom". Homosexuals don't even have to be "shoving it 
in your face" or "harassing the religious" to be discriminated against, the 
people running the business just have to SUSPECT that you MIGHT be a 
homosexual, and they then have legal grounds to deny you service.

That is why this bill is a pile of bigoted bullshit.
